bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, February 27, 1922

div1.p: Hanson reports on mosquito larvae studies in Peru. He also discusses, at length, administrative and political issues related to his work.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, February 27, 1922
div1.opener:
I. H. B.
Hanson
Sleg
DIRECTOR GENERAL
HENRY HANSON
M. D.
BAJO LOS AUSPICIOS DEL
GOBIERNO PERUANO Y LA
JUNTA INTERNACIONAL DE
SANIDAD DE ROCKEFELLER
FOUNDATION
Campaña Sanitaria contra la Fiebre Amarilla en el Perú
OFICINA CENTRAL
AVENIDA PIEROLA 545 - TELEFONO 3428
LIMA -- PERU February 27, 1922.
NUMERO
----
Dr. H.R. Carter,
Washington, D.C.
My daer Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
I have just received your letter of February 6th and
am sorry that due to the decision of Dr. Rose we are unable to giev you any-
thing except general observations, and few of those. This line of information
which you have asked for is a part of what we hoped to get by the work which
Dunn and I had in mind. I presume that by this time you have the letter which
I wrote you telling you that Dr. Rose had decided that he did not think it would
be worth while for Dunn to devote more than part time to the investigations which
we had mapped out. I presume that I had not given him sufficient details about
our work, as we had been pretty busy and I had only written in a very general
way about what I hoped to have Dunn do for us. As I told you before I think the
decision was a decided mistake and eliminates a very important piece of information
which we were in better position to get here than anywhere we have been before.
We have as you know an arid climate which introduces certain features of interest
in a study of this kind.

From the few observation which we have been able to make I think there is
no doubt about that the Pasteur Commission have set their temperatures too high.
We found the stegomya active and had them bite in the evenings at temperatures
of 17 C, and we noted in Trujillo where the temperatures fell pretty low at
night that we had practically a continuous new crop of young larvae. The men
kept finding new young larvae throughout the last winter season. In order to
make any authoritative statement it would be necessary to attempt to repeat
these observations in some sort of a Laboratory where one would have accurate
control so as to be able to judge about the conditions; whether all these young
larvae came from botijas in kitchens where the temperature was higher than the
official temperatures or whether it actually is a fact that they breed at these
(by us) observed lower temperatures. Dr. Cavassa has had more time and patience
in making observations of this kind than any of the rest of them. He recently
sent me a glass in which he had been conducting some experimental observations
on breeding and in this glass I found quite a number of the eggs attached to
the sides even though it had been shippedd from Guadelupe to Lima. In regard to
this feature Duhn claims that the eggs float to the sides and become attached
by means of a number of cup-like depressions (a sort of a suctions or cohesion
process) and that it is not the case that the Aedes (Stegomya) Aegyptus (Linnaeus)
a tually smears her eggs on the side of the container as we at one time thought
here.

In as much as this is Carnival Days, and as you know a species of fiesta
which prevents us from doing any work I am writing this at home, but will show
you letter to Dunn to-morrow or as soon as I see him and ask him to write you
what he knows about the points which you have brought up.

Well so far as Wrightson is concerned things seem to have come to a crisis
and the Minister of Fomento is insisting on his resignation, and W. has pre-
sented it, although up to date it has not been accepted by the President I think
it will be. There seems to be a sort of an impression here that it might cause
offense to the U.S.A. to discharge him. Some of us citizens of the U.S.A. have
intimated that we could not see that such could be the case when a discharge
could be made for cause. Unfortunately I have been drawn into this muddle as
2.
February 27, 1922.
Dr. H.R. Carter.
there has been quite a considerable demand that I take over the Salubridad
even if it only temporarily. His tennure of office has been even a bigger
mess than I previously thought it would be and certainly has not raised the
prestige of American Sanitarians in the country. I can not see where he
has done anything of any value to the country aside from getting Cardenas out of
the Office. It seems to me that all accomplishments are of a negative nature.

Saturday evening I cabled the International Health Board about the matter
asking their advise. I can hardly afford to take it and I dont want it; not
any more than Martha or Virgil like to take Castor oil. However there seems to
be some matters in connection with the financial arrangements and details of the
campaign which I could only hope for a proper adjustment of by taking the title
of “Direccion de Salubridad” for the few remaining months of the campaign. On
account of our practically Nation wide investigations I am almost forcibly con-
fined to Lima, and it might be possible to steer that almost rudderless ship
in addition to the part of our work which is still lacking. The thing which I
wanted to do in connection with work on the final general report would have to
be postponed if I did such a rash thing. In such a case I should make quite
extensive use of Dr. Lavoreria. I think I know more about the actual sanitary
conditions of the country than any other man they have got, and I also am be-
comming quite well informed about the trickery of their politics etc, and they
would not be able to put as many things over on me as they might have done
formerly. If I dont take it and they let W. out there are a string of political
aspirants for the job who have no qualifications whatever, and several of the
better class want me to take it if it is only temporarily to avoid a calamity
of that kind. Dr. Lavoreria and Dr. Ezayguirre (the statistician) are especially
anxious that I do that, I believe that they are sincere in wanting some ability
and dignity in the office. If I were a single man without family (I presume the
latter part of this remark would be taken for granted in the U.S.A.) I would
enjoy the fight for a year or two - there is no question about it being a fight f
for the man who stays with it - because there is literally everything to do.

I am hoping howev r that things will so adjust themselves that it will not
be necessary for me to have to mis up in this matter, I am like the soldier across
the sea - “I want to go home, I dont want to die”, and have been planning on
getting to the State in June or July at the latest.

I am glad to hear that you have considered writing the History of Yellow
Fever. It appears that you are the logical man to do it as you have played one
of the if not the biggest part in its control and elimination, and it seems
quite appropriate that you should write its history. I can well imagine that
it will be a big task, as the subject is quite big when one begins to go into
it in some detail.

I had had an idea of wanting to include a brief historical sketch, a
paragraph or two in what you might call the introductory part of our general
report on the recent Peruvian epidemics, but I have no literature from which
I might get a sort of bird's eye view of its history. Dr. Ezayguirre has written
a sort of a resume of the history of yellow fever in Peru up to the year 1906
which I have been reading a bit at times. It seems to me though that he draws
some erroneous conclusions at times (probably due to influences such as Dr.
Arce who did not want the worl to think that Peru has had quite as much yellow fe
fever as actually is the case). Dr. Ezayguirre is a pretty good fellow and
probably with the soundest judgement of all the men with whom I have had any-
thing to do in the Salubridad. Recently he came out openly in the Lima Academy
of Medicine and stated that he thought that probably all the cases which Dr.
Julian Arce had reported as biliosa hemoglobinurica, were cases of yellow fever.

I noticed when I stopped in the office this afternoon that Nelsons
had sent me the leaves of your article in NELSON'S LOOSE LEAF MEDICINE. I
have not had time to read them yet but have no doubt that we will find them
of great value. If I was not in doubts about securing the approval of
Nelsons I would also translate this and use extracts of it in some of our
publicity. I believe that I now have most of your articles, but there are still
some lacking. If you have copies of others which you could spare me temporarily
I should like to get them and put them all into spanish. For the near future it
will be more important to have these available in the spanish speaking countries
than anywhere else. When I think of this I feel as they say here sort of
“quejoso” that we were not able to get this work of Dunns to include with our
report and propaganda stuff, it would have so completely rounded out our cam-
paign and certainly would have shown up as one more big thing done through the
medium of the International Health Board and the Rockefeller Foundation. However
“no use to cry over spilled milk”.

Dr. Caballero, Mr. Dunn and Sr. Olivari have returned from their tour of
inspection in the south, and Caballero reports that there was nothing there in
the line of suspicious illness, but they found a high stegomya index all the
way to Moquegua. We shall make an inspection og Canete, and its port which is
Cerro Azul, and then we will have completed a survey of the entire coast of Peru.
We now know pretty well what the conditions are on the entire coast. We are still
having a little trouble with the breeding in such places as Barranca, Pativilca,
Supe and the port of Supe and also in Huarmey where on account of the very poor
steamship schedules we have been unable to do any work until recently. Still
taken as a whole I think we have the coast in very good shape and with a suffi-
ciently low index to prevent knowing the spread of yellow fever in all parts.

I want to arrange to start on a tour of inspection soon, and will endeavor
too look over as much of the old infected territory as possible. If we do not
find anything within the next month I think the job can be considered finished.

I will write you again as soon as I know what all our areas are
showing. It has been a pretty big proposition to try to keep in touch with all
parts of so extensive a territory as that which we now have.

With best wishes from all the family, and I might add here in
reply to your remarks about Virgil and Martha, that Virgil does not see any
reason why he should allow Martha or anyone else to interfere with any plan
or project which he may have under way. His psychology of just dealing is
that it is all just when it comes out his way, but not otherwise.
